text:
PROFESSOR: There
are several mediums

of working with students in
the process of designing.
There are desk-side crits.
There are reviews.
There are lectures.
And there are pinups.

In this studio, every week,
a piece of the project

is due, whether it be
a model or a drawing.

And we have what we call pin
up, when all the students pin up

their work and quickly
explain what they are doing.

And then I and other
members of the class

try to give comments
on what they've

seen to try to help
to the next step.

Because architecture
is not just one step.

It's a continual
process that changes.

Perhaps people have the idea
that it comes all at once.
It doesn't.
It comes over a period of time.

So the pin up is a very
valuable part of that.

Because it's giving
students a feedback
as to how they're moving.

And slowly, adjustments
are made for the next step.

So what you're about
to see is a typical pin

up of which happens almost
every week during the semester.

STUDENT: When I first
visited the site,

I was pretty amazed by
the view, obviously.
Because we're up on the roof.

We get to look over
all of the north end.

And I unfortunately,
am blocked from Boston.
I have a wall.
There's a better view.
Well, there's a wall on the--
what side is that?
Is this the east?
PROFESSOR: Yeah, the east.
STUDENT: East side?
PROFESSOR: Yeah.

STUDENT: Well, on the
east side there's a wall.
So I can't see Boston.

But I see all of the
harbor and the north end.

Anyway, that wall is going
to act as my entrance.
It's perfect for that.

But I still want to be
able to see over that.

I'd love to have my bedroom
like looking over Boston.
That would be pretty cool.

So my idea was to have my
main floor below the wall

and then have some kind
of spiral staircase

that leads up to a room on
posts, looking over Boston,

and another one that's
looking out over the harbor.

In 10 years, I see myself
happily married with a firm
of my own, successful firm.
AUDIENCE: Architecture firm?
STUDENT: Architectural firm.
And yeah, so no kids.
PROFESSOR: No kids?
STUDENT: No kids.
No time.

PROFESSOR: How
about cats or dogs?

STUDENT: Actually, I
didn't think about that.
I'll think more on that.

Anyway, my needs would be
a bedroom, a guest bedroom,

two bathrooms, a kitchen,
dining room, and a study.

And I'd like the study to be
the other room that's elevated.

That would be the one
looking over the harbor.

And then my bedroom would
be looking over Boston.
Oh, my site clue, funny story.

So I was going up
on a fire escape

to get photos of my site,
this photo actually.
You can see the fire escape.
I got up there.
And the thing is horrible.
It is rusty.

And it's about to fall
down, the entire thing.

And about every step,
something was shaking.

And finally, I
stepped on one step.
And it just completely gave way.

And then it clink, clink,
clink all the way down
and landed on the ground.

So I didn't think of bringing
it back as a site clue
until later.

And I went up and saw
the Paul Revere thing.

And then someone helped
me think of it, that that
would be an amazing site clue.
So I went back.
And it was lying on the ground.
So I grabbed it.

Yeah, so it's pretty
straightforward.
It should be fun.
OK, I was inspired--
I think these are granaries.
I don't know exactly.

But they're just
cylindrical and metal.
And there's a barn underneath.

And I kind of want a
rectangular main floor

with a kind of metallic, spiral
staircase, and then these rooms

off shooting as curved,
like partial circles.

I want to capture
the panoramic view,
like is done on this corner.
It's curved.
So you can see the hole.
So I like that a lot.

So that was the way I
wanted to incorporate it.

PROFESSOR: And I'm just going to
pump for some more information.
STUDENT: Sure.

PROFESSOR: What about the
area or the north end?
How did you react to it?

STUDENT: Oh, I really
like the rooftop view.
What do you mean north end?

PROFESSOR: Well,
the north end is

a very special kind of
physical neighborhood,
as well as social.
In the United States--

STUDENT: It was very
touristy, I noticed.

And I like the roof, because you
get away from all the tourists.
And I agree with you.

There's like a completely
separate world up there.

I know personally, like
my roof of my house

right now, if you
go up there, there's

people having parties
randomly on rooftops.

And it's kind of cool
just to check it out.

And I went by to
one the other day.

The next door
neighbors were having

like a barbecue and
everything on their roof.
So that was kind of cool.

But I think that's going
to happen a lot here.

So I want to have
roof access as well.

PROFESSOR: Well, for
me, seeing the site

for the first time is one
of the most exciting parts
of architecture.

I can't sleep the night
before when I see a site.

And I was curious how
you people were going
to react to the north end.
AUDIENCE: [INAUDIBLE]
PROFESSOR: The night before?
I find I'm like a kid.
I'm up all night.

I'm going to see a
new site next week.

And I just-- I can't
wait to see it.

AUDIENCE: I was conserving
my energy for last night.
PROFESSOR: Uh-huh.

AUDIENCE: I was up all
night doing [INAUDIBLE]..

PROFESSOR: Well, that's a
little different problem.

And I got another site
from Turkey today,
which I have to go for--

I will be going on a Friday
and coming back on a Monday

morning in a couple
of weeks or so.

But I saw the site
in photographs.

And it's very exciting
to see a new site.

So I was curious to see how
you folks would react to that.
A couple of things.
Good start, guys, as always.

You guys always
have good starts.

In Philip's case, a couple
of things that I thought
were interesting.

He did not tell us that
his site is probably

one of the most important ones,
because-- where did he go?
There he is.

He is the busybody,
or the caretaker,
of our public site down below.

The other thing is immediately
jumping from the program,
no kids or one kid?
I can't remember.
No kids, OK.
That's good.

Because you may lose
them all up here in the--

AUDIENCE: He can just put
them in the [INAUDIBLE]..
PROFESSOR: Right.
That's what this could be.

What's quickly very interesting
about this sketch from where

he is is that we have a
delicate kind of dance

between contextual and
non-contextual architecture,

that which fits and that
which doesn't, which

was the case with
the last project.
It's no different.

It's always the
case, whether it's

a quarry as we're using this
or a so-called natural quarry,
as the last one.

What I find interesting is that
this kind of vocabulary, which

we can start to imagine fits
in very much to the roof scapes
that we know.

For instance, those
who are from New York,

you will find every roof
has a water tower on it.

And here we don't
for some reason.
I'm not sure why.

But the kind of form that
this is starting to suggest,

suggests that it's part of
the roof, part of the sky.
I don't know how it works yet.

But I think your decision
of using the back wall

to move into it and using
this as a generator, a very
strong generator, of the view--

and then I'm not
sure what this is--

moving off of this
is very powerful.
So it's a good start, Philip.

What we've got to do now is
to make this work in plan.

I mean, there's
no plan there yet.
There's ideas.
But the idea is there.

The conceptual form
making is very strong.

I would invite you
to use this as a clue

as to what kind of architecture
you might find up here.

A light steel
construction might work.
AUDIENCE: [INAUDIBLE]
AUDIENCE: [INAUDIBLE]

PROFESSOR: Yeah, as
opposed to heavy.
This is heavy.

But the notion of the
skeleton kind of form

might be another interesting
way of being up there.

STUDENT: So my
first idea is when

I got to the north
end, the first things

that I noticed were
just the fact that there
is a lot of layering.

And I like the
fact that material
merged into other materials.

Here I tried to mimic
the cobblestones

in the street and
then the pavement,

how it just merged
into the pavement.

Just that idea I liked
a lot, how materials
merged into other materials.

And this is the
facade of my building.
Here is where we met.
And my building is--
it's really two buildings.

And my site is either on top of
both or on top of one of them.

And I'm thinking of taking
over both sides for now.

But what I liked a lot about
the facade, just looking at it,

is the fact that you can tell
the history of the building.

You can see how it
has evolved over time.

This is somewhat different
to the next level,

which is somewhat different
to the next level.
But they merge.

I like the way the
materials merged.

And I want my
building, my apartment,

to merge with that, to be
another layer of the building.
So that's my main idea.

I envision myself
being married, I think.

At first I thought,
well, I'm not sure.

There's so much to do
before getting married, so

many places to visit in the
world that I wanted to visit.

But right across from
this is the playground.

And I sat in the
little playground.

And I thought, this would
be really nice to have kids.
So I hopefully will be married.
And if I am, I'd have two kids.

But if I wasn't, I think at
that point I'd adopt a child.

And if I live here,
I have to have a kid.

There's a beautiful
playground right across.

So just the community
seemed very friendly.

When I was there, I
talked to a woman.
And she had her child with her.
And just a very open--

it seemed like a lot
of parents were there.

So this idea of merging and
this idea of creating layers,

I decided that I
would use the facade

to guide the way that
I was going to design.

Because I couldn't get
myself away from this idea

that I want the
materials to merge.

I just couldn't start
thinking about what

the form of the
building would be.

So what I did was I just
decided that I'd make a grid.

I feel like I have a
lot of leeway here.

I have a site that doesn't have
a problem, such as Sarah's.

Sarah has [INAUDIBLE]
she has to deal with.

I feel like I don't have such
a problem that is prominent.

And so I need some parameters
to help me try to design.

So part of my program would be
I wanted to have a fencing room.

Because I saw myself as
either an assistant coach
or a competitive fencer.

But I was told that would be a
better idea for the community
center.

So I can coach
there, if I need to.

PROFESSOR: Well, you might
fall off the roof is the point.

STUDENT: But I do want
a garden, I think.
I love gardens.
I love trees.

And I'd like some way to have
a garden surrounding the house

to make [INAUDIBLE]
buildings right
at this very little corner.
They merge.
And they continue.
And so I like that idea.

And I'm thinking even there
having my chimney just extend
from there.

This is another view from
the back, from the alley,
just to see where things are.
And that's Sarah's site.
And mine's right on top.
So maybe we can--
I don't know-- get together.

But I don't have any idea
what my form of my building
is going to be.

I think the last
couple of days has just

given me the opportunity
to think about what kind
of parameters I want.

PROFESSOR: I think
that's interesting for me

to see how people
relate to the north end.

And one of the reasons
why I chose the north end

is that it's a very rich place
architecturally, socially.

And she has found
this notion that she

calls merging of
materials, time,

which is what the north end is
all about is a merging of time.

And we get Paul Revere
around the corner.

But we can find young
professionals living here.
So there's a merging over time.

And also, that results,
I think, in what
happens here of the style.

I'd like to, as I mentioned
to her the other day,

to consider another word, which
I will talk about on Thursday,
which is layering.

There are layers of different
time or different materials

in the north end, which is quite
different than any place else
that we would be.

You have the layers of
different materials.

The fire escapes, for me,
is a layer of something

against the hardness,
very skeleton.

So this notion, as
indicated by the sketch--

by the way, how
many kids we got?

One, three, and two, so
we've got six already.

It beats last year's
class, where we only
had three I think.

And incidentally,
the observation

is very revealing of the
north end as a playground,

if you think about the
exposure of children or us

to other people, which is
quite different than if we

had to pick the site
in the suburbs, which
we wouldn't have.

Because this has a lot of
opportunities for exposures,
all kinds of exposure.

You meet somebody
from Iowa walking up.

And I found-- I have asked
you, but I continually

find that the North Enders
are friendly people.
They'll stop and talk with you.

I never have been challenged,
unlike the suburbs.

You go to the suburbs and
you try to talk to someone,

you'll be arrested
probably on the spot.
Because you're up to no good.
But that's not the case here.
It's a very public thing.

So I thought that was an
interesting observation.

But I just want to pick up on
this, which she has suggested
in a geometric way.

And I think she's
actually suggested

in an architectural way what
I would like to talk about.

But in plan, if this is the
roof, that these layers might
not necessarily--

these are planes of part of
the floor, and the walls,
I should say--

may not at all line
up with the old layer.
They may miss it, in two ways.

This is, if you're following
me, this is a setback of a plan.

This is her garden
and her design.
This is light comes through.
But that's one way.

And then the other way,
if that's the boundary,

the layers could come out,
which we may see in others.

So instead of a direct
interpretation of it,

you could think of this
as coming up to here.
And the geometry picked up.

But the layers are
maybe set back,

which means that on
top of this, then

we have these kind of
transitions, or layers,
of different materials.

And they could be
entirely different.

You didn't talk about
the roof form, sky form.

You may need a cloud
floating by or something.
Think about that.

But that quality of this sketch
is very powerful on that place.
So I think that's a great start.
